title: Shakespeare and the Invention of Late Writing: Authorship, Biography, Reception
abstractText: A reception history which accounts the construction of Shakespeare's last years as an exemplar of 'late writing' - the idea that certain creative artist, late in life, enter a period of fresh creativity characterised in particular ways (e.g. serenity, looseness of fiction, a return to the early). I explore the idea from Shakespeare's day to the present, relating the history of its invention from origins in early modern life-writing to its establishment as a critical given in the later nineteenth century and demonstrating the ways in which it fundamentally misrepresents early modern theatrical authorship and thus Shakespeare's late plays themselves.
